title: Complaints – General Principles
body_md:
{{firm.name}} will deal promptly and fairly with complaints (as defined below) referred to it in respect of its business activities carried on from establishments in the United Kingdom.
{{firm.name}} defines a complaint using the definition contained in the FCA glossary, namely:
| Any oral or written expression of dissatisfaction, whether justified or not, from, or on behalf of, a person about the provision of, or failure to provide, a financial service or a redress determination, which: (a) alleges that the complainant has suffered (or may suffer) financial loss, material distress or material inconvenience; and (b) relates to an activity of that firm, or of any other firm with whom that firm has some connection in marketing or providing financial services or products, which comes under the jurisdiction of the Financial Ombudsman Service. |
| --- |

In order to review these complaints, {{firm.name}} has in place and operates an appropriate and effective procedure for registering and responding to complaints from eligible complainants, as defined in the FCA’s DISP rules (DISP 2.7.3R).

title: Wider Eligibility for PSD Complaints
body_md:
- any payment service user (as defined in regulation 2 of the PSRs 2017) may complain, even if they do not meet the DISP “eligible complainant” test
- {{firm.name}} will still apply the DISP standards when dealing with ineligible PSD complainants
{{firm.name}} will review and respond to all complaints on a case-by-case basis where they are received from complainants who are not defined as eligible.

title: Consumer Duty in Complaints Handling
body_md:
{{firm.name}} is committed to upholding the FCA's Consumer Duty in its complaints handling processes, ensuring good outcomes for retail customers across all four outcome areas.
- Products and Services
- Regularly review complaint data to identify potential issues with product design or delivery
- Use complaints insights to inform product development and improvements
- Ensure complaints handlers have comprehensive product knowledge to address customer concerns effectively
- Price and Value
- Analyse complaints related to pricing to ensure products and services continue to offer fair value
- Address any systemic issues identified in complaints about fees or charges promptly
- Consider fair value when determining appropriate redress for upheld complaints
- Consumer Understanding
- Use plain language in all complaint communications to ensure clarity and comprehension
- Provide clear explanations of complex terms or processes when responding to complaints
- Use complaint trends to improve customer communications and product information
- Consumer Support
- Offer multiple channels for lodging and discussing complaints to suit customer preferences
- Provide additional support for vulnerable customers throughout the complaints process
- Ensure complaint handlers are trained to deliver high-quality, empathetic customer service
Implementation Across the Complaints Journey
| Complaint Stage | Consumer Duty Consideration |
| --- | --- |
| Receipt | Ensure ease of complaint submission across various channels |
| Acknowledgement | Provide clear information on the complaints process and expected timelines |
| Investigation | Consider whether the complaint indicates a breach of the Consumer Duty |
| Resolution | Ensure the resolution supports good customer outcomes |
| Root Cause Analysis | Identify and address any systemic issues that may breach the Consumer Duty |
| Reporting | Include Consumer Duty considerations in complaints MI and board reporting |

Example: A customer complains about difficulty understanding the terms of their remittance transfer. In line with the Consumer Duty, {{firm.name}} would:
- Review the complaint in the context of the 'Consumer Understanding' outcome
- Investigate whether this is a systemic issue affecting other customers
- Implement improvements to the T&Cs documentation to enhance clarity
- Provide the complainant with a clear, jargon-free explanation of the terms
- Consider whether the lack of understanding has led to any detriment requiring redress
By embedding Consumer Duty principles throughout our complaints handling process, {{firm.name}} ensures that we not only resolve individual issues but also drive improvements that benefit all customers and support the delivery of good outcomes.

{{firm.name}} is committed to establishing, implementing, and maintaining effective and transparent procedures for the prompt handling of complaints in compliance with FCA DISP and PSR regulations. These procedures are designed to ensure that eligible complainants can make complaints free of charge and by any reasonable means. {{firm.name}} aims to resolve all complaints promptly, fairly, and in line with FCA principles, particularly ensuring the fair treatment of customers under Principle 6.

title: Complaint Handling Framework
body_md:
{{firm.name}} has implemented a robust complaint handling framework which ensures:
- Complaints can be made free of charge by any eligible complainant through any reasonable communication channel, such as phone, email, post, or online.
- {{firm.name}} recognises all complaints as requiring timely and effective resolution. All complaints will be acknowledged within five business days and resolved as quickly as possible, following the time limits outlined under DISP 1.6.
- Where complaints are resolved by the close of the third business day after receipt, {{firm.name}} will issue a Summary Resolution Communication (SRC) in compliance with DISP 1.5. The SRC will inform the complainant of their right to refer the complaint to the Financial Ombudsman ServiceFOS within six months if they are not satisfied with the outcome.

title: Digital Complaints Handling
body_md:

{{firm.name}} recognises the growing importance of digital channels in customer interactions and has implemented robust processes to handle complaints received through these platforms effectively.

title: Process for Handling Digital Complaints
body_md:
- Monitoring and Identification:
- Continuous monitoring of website submissions and email during business hours
- Regular monitoring of X/Twitter account
- Clear classification of general enquiries vs. formal complaints
- Acknowledgement:
- Automated acknowledgement sent within 1 business day of complaint receipt via website or email
- Public acknowledgement on X/Twitter within 4 business hours during working hours
- Unique reference number assigned to each complaint for tracking
- Triage and Allocation:
- Complaints categorised based on urgency and complexity
- High-priority complaints (e.g., those indicating financial distress) escalated for immediate handling
- Investigation and Resolution:
- Standard complaints handling process followed, regardless of channel of origin
- Option for customers to switch to their preferred communication channel during the process
- Response:
- Responses provided through the customer's preferred channel (email or website messaging system)
- Public acknowledgement on X/Twitter with request to move to private channel for detailed response

title: Handling X/Twitter Complaints:
body_md:
- Acknowledge publicly (e.g., "We're sorry to hear about your experience. We've sent you a direct message to assist further.")
- Move the conversation to a private channel (e.g., direct message)
- Capture complaint details and follow standard complaints process
- Provide resolution privately, with a public follow-up if appropriate and with customer's consent (e.g., "We're glad we could resolve your issue. Thank you for bringing this to our attention.")

title: Example: A customer tweets about difficulties understanding the remittance fees. MFS would:
body_md:
- Acknowledge the tweet publicly within 4 business hours
- Send a direct message to gather more details
- Log the complaint in the CMS system
- Assign to a complaints handler specialising in product clarity issues
- Resolve the complaint following standard procedures
- Respond privately with a detailed explanation and any necessary redress
- Post a public follow-up (with customer's permission) about the resolution

title: Quality Assurance for Digital Complaints
body_md:
- Regular audits of digital complaints handling to ensure consistency with other channels
- Monitoring of response times and resolution rates for digital complaints
- Customer satisfaction surveys specific to digital complaint resolution

title: Specific Considerations for Email Complaints
body_md:
- Implement robust spam filters to ensure genuine complaints are not missed
- Use auto-responders outside of business hours to set expectations for response times
- Ensure email servers have sufficient capacity to handle high volumes during peak complaint periods

title: Website Complaint Form Enhancements
body_md:
- Implement clear categorisation options to help route complaints effectively
- Include an urgency indicator for customers to self-identify high-priority issues
- Provide immediate on-screen confirmation of complaint submission in addition to email acknowledgement
In line with DISP 1.3.7, {{firm.name}} has appointed a dedicated individual, Misah Maragh, as the Compliance Officer responsible for the oversight of the firm’s adherence to DISP rules.

title: Monitoring Complaints Made Against MFS
body_md:
{{firm.name}} will implement a structured approach to monitor complaints made directly against itself:
- Complaints Monitoring System: All complaints raised against {{firm.name}} are logged in its Complaints Management System (CMS), enabling the Compliance Team to monitor trends, identify systemic issues, and ensure ongoing compliance with FCA rules.
- Regular Review: Complaints data will be reviewed monthly by senior management, with trends and patterns documented and submitted as part of the “Complaints Monitoring Report” to the board for review at quarterly meetings.
- Key Performance Indicators (KPIs): {{firm.name}} will monitor key complaint metrics, including resolution times, repeat complaints, and the effectiveness of root cause analysis. Where patterns suggest systemic issues, {{firm.name}} will escalate them for further investigation and resolution.

title: Compliance with FCA Principle 6 – Customers’ Interests
body_md:
In accordance with FCA Principle 6, {{firm.name}} commits to ensuring that customers’ interests are placed at the heart of its complaints handling process. This means:
- When {{firm.name}} identifies any problems, root causes, or compliance failures through complaints or monitoring, it will proactively take steps to resolve the issue for all affected customers, including those who may have been disadvantaged but did not formally complain.
- If a complaint reveals a root cause that could affect a wider group of customers, {{firm.name}} will consider taking corrective action for the benefit of all affected customers. This could include product adjustments, refunds, or process improvements.

title: Reporting to the FOS
body_md:
{{firm.name}} ensures that complainants are informed of their rights to escalate their complaint to the FOS, as per DISP 1.4. Complainants will be provided with:
- Final Response Letter: If a complaint is unresolved after fifteen days (with 35-day contingency), {{firm.name}} will issue a Final Response Letter, clearly detailing the customer’s right to refer their complaint to FOS and the relevant time limits for doing so.
- Six-Month Time Limit: The Summary Resolution Communication (SRC) and Final Response Letter will include a reminder that the complainant has six months to refer their complaint to FOS if they are not satisfied with {{firm.name}}’s final response.
“You have the right to refer your complaint to the Financial Ombudsman Service, free of charge – but you must do so within six months of the date of this letter.”

{{firm.name}} has implemented a robust complaints handling process designed to meet the highest standards of customer service and regulatory compliance under Part 7 of the Payment Services Regulations 2017 (PSRs) for payment services, including money remittance.

title: Complaints Handling Process for Payment Services (PSRs)
body_md:
For complaints related to payment services (including money remittance and cross-border payments), {{firm.name}} complies with Part 7 of the Payment Services Regulations 2017. The complaints process under the PSRs is designed to ensure swift resolution of payment disputes, with stricter acknowledgement and resolution timelines.
Steps for Complaint Handling

title: Acknowledgement of Receipt (PSRs)
body_md:
- {{firm.name}} will acknowledge receipt of any payment services complaint within one business day, in accordance with PSR Regulation 101. The acknowledgment will provide:
- Confirmation of receipt.
- Contact details of the Payment Services Complaint Handler.
- Information on the complaint handling process.
Example: A customer raising a complaint about delayed money transfers will receive an acknowledgment within one business day, outlining the next steps.

title: Information Gathering and Investigation (PSRs)
body_md:
- {{firm.name}} will investigate the complaint competently and impartially, gathering:
- Transaction records
- Remittance agreements
- Customer communications and related documentation
- The investigation will consider all relevant factors, including any third-party involvement in the payment process.

title: Resolution Timeline (PSRs)
body_md:
- Under Regulation 101 of the PSRs, {{firm.name}} is required to resolve the complaint and provide a Final Response within 15 business days of receiving the complaint. If additional time is needed due to exceptional circumstances, this may be extended to 35 business days, but the complainant must be notified within the initial 15-day period.
- The Final Response will detail:
- The decision on whether the complaint is upheld or dismissed.
- Any redress or remedial action offered.
- The customer’s right to escalate the complaint to theFOS, including the six-month time limit for doing so.
Example: If a customer submits a complaint regarding unexpected fees on a cross-border transaction, {{firm.name}} will aim to resolve the issue within 15 business days, providing a Final Response with a clear explanation of the fees and any proposed redress.

title: Remedial Action and Redress
body_md:
- If the complaint is upheld, {{firm.name}} will promptly implement any remedial action (e.g., fee refunds or adjustments to transaction terms) and confirm the outcome in writing.
For unresolved PSD complaints we will signpost eligible complainants to the Financial Ombudsman Service and all other complainants to the Payment Systems Regulator, in line with DISP 1.1A.30UK–31UK and regulation 101(2)(c) PSRs 2017

title: Factors Considered in Complaint Resolution
body_md:
{{firm.name}} applies a consistent approach across Payment Services complaints, considering several key factors in every investigation:
- All available evidence, including contracts, terms, and communication records
- The specific circumstances of the complaint, including whether the complainant is a vulnerable customer
- FOS and regulatory guidance (including DISP and PSRs) to ensure decisions are in line with industry standards
- Patterns of complaints that may indicate broader systemic issues

title: Preventing Escalation to FOS
body_md:
{{firm.name}} aims to resolve complaints promptly to minimise referrals to the FOS by:
- Proactive Resolution: Whenever possible, {{firm.name}} will issue a SRC within three business days, confirming the resolution of the complaint. This early intervention reduces the likelihood of customer dissatisfaction and FOS referrals.
- Customer Communication: For complaints that cannot be resolved immediately, {{firm.name}} will maintain regular contact with the complainant, ensuring they are informed of the status of the investigation and feel reassured about the process.

title: Cooperation with the FOS
body_md:
In cases where complaints are escalated to the FOS, {{firm.name}} will:
- Cooperate fully with the FOS investigation.
- Provide all relevant documentation and information promptly to support the investigation.
- Implement any decisions or awards made by the FOS in a timely manner, ensuring full compliance with any settlements or compensation ordered.

title: Complaints Resolved Within Three Business Days
body_md:
| Regulation References •DISP 1.5.1R (Complaints Resolved Within Three Business Days) •DISP 1.5.4R (Summary Resolution Communication) •Payment Services Regulations 2017 (PSRs), Part 7 |
| --- |

{{firm.name}} ({{firm.name}}) has established a streamlined process for resolving complaints swiftly and efficiently, in compliance with DISP 1.5.1R and PSRs, aiming to resolve complaints by the close of business on the third business day following the day of receipt. Complaints resolved within this three-business-day period are still subject to key complaint handling requirements, though certain time limit and forwarding rules may not apply. This approach ensures quick resolutions without compromising regulatory standards.

title: Scope and Applicability
body_md:
{{firm.name}} follows the rules set out by DISP for complaints resolved within three business days. The following exceptions apply for these quick resolutions:
- The complaints time limit rules do not apply.
- The complaints forwarding rules are not triggered.
However, all other relevant complaint resolution rules under DISP 1 still apply, ensuring that complaints are handled fairly, even when resolved quickly.
For the purposes of this section:
- A complaint received on a non-business day (or after the close of business) is considered received on the next business day.
- A complaint is deemed resolved when the complainant indicates acceptance of {{firm.name}}’s response, with no requirement for this acceptance to be in writing.

title: Step 1: Acknowledgment of Receipt
body_md:
When a complaint is received directly by {{firm.name}}, {{firm.name}} will:
- Acknowledge receipt of the complaint immediately, ensuring that it is recorded in the Complaints Management System.
- Ensure that the complaint is logged and assigned to the appropriate Complaint Handler to assess the potential for a resolution within three business days.

title: Step 2: Investigation and Resolution
body_md:
{{firm.name}} will promptly investigate the complaint with a goal to resolve it by close of business on the third business day following the receipt of the complaint. The investigation will involve:
- Reviewing all relevant documentation (e.g., contracts, terms, customer communications) to understand the issue fully.
- Assessing the complaint fairly and transparently, taking into account the complainant’s specific concerns..
{{firm.name}} will seek to reach an agreement with the complainant as quickly as possible, without compromising the thoroughness of the investigation. For example, if a customer complains about an unexpected remittance fee, {{firm.name}} will review the documentation and offer a clear explanation or fee adjustment if warranted.

title: Step 3: Summary Resolution Communication (SRC)
body_md:
If {{firm.name}} resolves the complaint within three business days, it will issue a SRC, as required by DISP 1.5.4R. This written communication will be sent to the complainant immediately upon resolution, confirming that the issue has been resolved and providing the necessary regulatory information.
The SRC must contain the following elements:

title: Reference to the Complaint
body_md:
- The SRC will clearly state that the complainant had made a complaint, and {{firm.name}} now considers the complaint resolved.
Example: “We understand you raised a concern regarding your agreement. We are pleased to confirm that we have resolved the issue.”

title: Right to Escalate to the FOS
body_md:
- The SRC will inform the complainant that if they are dissatisfied with the resolution, they have the right to escalate the complaint to the FOS.
- This must include an explanation of the time limits for referring the complaint to the FOS as outlined in DISP 2.8.2R (i.e., within six months of receiving {{firm.name}}’s final response).

title: FOS Time Limits
body_md:
- The SRC will indicate whether {{firm.name}} consents to waive the relevant time limits for referring the complaint to the FOS. This is essential when complaints are resolved outside the standard timeframe but the complainant may still wish to pursue further resolution.
- The wording of this clause will comply with DISP 1 Annex 3R, ensuring that the time limits and rights are clearly communicated.

title: FOS Website and Contact Information
body_md:
- The SRC will provide the website address of the Financial Ombudsman Service.
- It will also include a note about the availability of further information on the FOS website for the complainant’s reference.

title: Further FOS Information
body_md: - The SRC will inform the complainant of the additional resources available on the FOS website, including how to proceed if they are unsatisfied with {{firm.name}}’s resolution.

title: Step 4: Compliance with Resolution
body_md:
If the complainant accepts the resolution provided by {{firm.name}}, the firm will ensure that it promptly implements any redress or remedial action. This could include:
- Updating internal records in the Complaints Management System to document the resolution and track any further actions required.

title: Monitoring and Reporting for Three-Day Resolutions
body_md:
Even for complaints resolved within three business days, {{firm.name}} will:
- Log all complaints and resolutions in the central Complaints Management System to ensure compliance with DISP 1.5.6R.
- Track patterns in three-day resolutions to identify any recurring issues or systemic problems that could indicate a broader concern.
- Report on complaint trends in the quarterly compliance review, ensuring that lessons are learned and improvements are made where necessary.
For instance, if multiple complaints are resolved quickly but relate to the same product feature (e.g., unclear terms in payment remittance service), {{firm.name}} will initiate a product review to address potential misunderstandings or flaws in the product design.

title: Exceptions and Escalations
body_md:
In cases where the complaint is not resolved within three business days:
- {{firm.name}} will escalate the complaint to the full complaint handling process, adhering to the standard DISP time limits.
- The complainant will be kept informed throughout the process, and {{firm.name}} will ensure that the investigation continues promptly and fairly, with the goal of resolution as soon as possible.
This ensures that all complaints—whether resolved quickly or requiring further investigation—are handled with the same level of care, diligence, and regulatory compliance.

title: Complaints Time Limit Rules
body_md:
| Regulatory Reference: •DISP 1.6 (Complaints Time Limits) •Payment Services Regulations (PSRs) 2017, Part 7 (Dispute Resolution) |
| --- |

{{firm.name}} recognises the importance of adhering to the FCA's time limits for complaints. The rules differ depending on the type of complaint:
- For Payment Services (PSD) Complaints: We will aim to issue a Final Response within 15 business days of receiving the complaint. If, in exceptional circumstances, we are unable to do so, we will send a holding response clearly explaining the delay and providing a final deadline of no more than 35 business days from the date the complaint was received.
- For All Other Complaints (Non-PSD): We will issue a Final Response within 8 weeks (56 days) of receiving the complaint. If we are unable to provide a Final Response within this period, we will send a holding letter that explains the reason for the delay and informs the complainant of their right to refer their complaint to the Financial Ombudsman Service.

title: Acknowledgement of Complaints
body_md:
{{firm.name}} recognises the importance of early acknowledgment of complaints to provide complainants with reassurance that their issue is being addressed. Upon receipt of a complaint, {{firm.name}} will:
- Acknowledge the complaint in writing promptly, using the Acknowledgement Letter Template. This letter confirms that {{firm.name}} has received the complaint and is actively dealing with it.
- Assign a Complaint Handler responsible for monitoring the investigation, with a commitment to resolving the complaint as efficiently as possible.
The acknowledgment letter will provide:
- A reassurance that {{firm.name}} has received the complaint and is working towards a resolution.
- Contact information for the Compliance Officer overseeing the complaint.
If additional information from the complainant is required, {{firm.name}} will request this promptly through the General Contact Letter, ensuring that efforts are made to contact the complainant via phone before sending a written request.
After the initial acknowledgment, {{firm.name}} will:
- Provide written updates on the progress of the investigation, including any delays or additional steps being taken to resolve the complaint.
- Ensure the complainant is informed of any substantial developments, such as the need for further information or the involvement of third-party entities, to maintain transparency.

title: General contact letter
body_md:
This letter should be issued to the customer where {{firm.name}} requires more information about the complaint from the customer, but after attempting to call them over three days has been unable to reach them. The General Contact Letter Template should be used for this. The letter will be issued in the name of the Compliance Officer who will approve the letter prior to issue.
Handling of PSD complaints
PSD complaints and general complaints under DISP will be thoroughly assessed and appropriately routed to ensure they are addressed in a timely and effective manner. At {{firm.name}}, we are committed to the swift and fair resolution of complaints related to Payment Services Directive (PSD) issues. Understanding the importance of these services to our clients, we adhere to specific resolution timelines as follows:
- Three Business Day Rule: We aim to resolve any PSD-related complaints within three business days of receipt. Upon resolution, we will provide the complainant with a written confirmation detailing the resolution and any actions taken.
- Fifteen Business Days: If a PSD complaint cannot be resolved within the initial three business days, we will inform the complainant of the ongoing process. Communication will be provided no later than fifteen business days from the date the complaint was received, explaining the reasons for the delay and the investigations being undertaken.
- Thirty-Five Business Days: Should the complaint require further investigation beyond fifteen business days, a final notice will be issued to the complainant by the thirty-fifth business day. This notice will detail the current status of their complaint and the expected resolution timeline. It will also inform the complainant about their right to escalate the matter to theFOS if they are dissatisfied with the progress or outcome.
- Final Response: Once the investigation is complete, {{firm.name}} will issue a formal written response to the complainant. This response will outline the findings of the investigation, the final decision regarding the complaint, and any actions to be taken or compensation to be provided. It will also guide the complainant on how to escalate their complaint to the FOS should they remain dissatisfied with the decision or handling of the complaint.
For all other complaints, the 8-week rule applies.

title: Handling Complaints From Vulnerable Customers
body_md:
| Regulatory References FG21/1 (FCA Guidance on the Fair Treatment of Vulnerable Customers) PRIN 6 (Customers' Interests) PRIN 2A (Consumer Duty) |
| --- |

{{firm.name}} recognises the importance of providing additional support to vulnerable customers throughout the complaints process, ensuring fair outcomes and appropriate assistance.

title: Identification of Vulnerable Complainants
body_md:
- Review existing customer records for vulnerability flags.
- Train complaints handlers to recognise potential vulnerabilities during interactions.
- Implement a 'soft facts' gathering approach in all complaint communications.

title: Additional Support Measures
body_md:
- Communication:
- Offer multiple communication channels (phone, email, letter).
- Provide communications in accessible formats (large print, audio, Braille).
- Allow more time for vulnerable customers to process information and respond.
- Complaint Handling:
- Assign dedicated, specially trained staff to handle vulnerable customer complaints
- Offer to involve a trusted third party (e.g., family member, carer) if the customer wishes
- Conduct a 'double-check' review of all decisions related to vulnerable customer complaints
- Resolution:
- Consider the impact of vulnerability on the complaint circumstances
- Ensure any redress or compensation takes into account the customer's vulnerable circumstances
Example: A customer with a mental health condition complains about difficulty understanding their remittance terms. {{firm.name}} would:
- Assign a specialist complaints handler trained in mental health awareness.
- Offer a verbal explanation of the terms, followed by a simplified written summary.
- Allow extra time for the customer to consider the explanation and ask questions.
- Conduct a review of how the product was initially sold to ensure it was appropriate for the customer's circumstances.
Table: Vulnerability Considerations in Complaints Handling
| Complaint Stage | Standard Approach | Enhanced Approach for Vulnerable Customers |
| --- | --- | --- |
| Receipt | Acknowledge within 5 days | Acknowledge within 2 days, offer immediate call-back |
| Investigation | Standard information gathering | Additional care to understand impact of vulnerability on the issue |
| Communication | Regular updates as investigation progresses | More frequent, simplified updates; check customer understanding |
| Resolution | Standard decision letter | Tailored communication of decision, offer follow-up call to explain |
| Redress | Standard compensation calculations | Consider additional compensation for distress and inconvenience related to vulnerability |

title: Speed And Quality Of Response
body_md:
| Regulatory References: •DISP 1.6.2R (Complaints Handling Time Limits) •DISP 1.6.4R (Holding Responses) •DISP 1.4.1R (General Complaint Handling) |
| --- |

{{firm.name}} recognises that both the speed and quality of its response to complaints are critical.
- For PSD Complaints: we are committed to providing a Final Response within 15 business days. If this is not possible in exceptional circumstances, we will provide a holding response within this 15-day period, with a clear explanation and a final deadline of 35 business days.
- For all other complaints: we will issue a Final Response within 8 weeks (56 days) of receiving the complaint. If a Final Response cannot be issued within this timeframe, we will send a holding response that clearly explains the delay, provides an estimated resolution date, and informs the complainant of their right to refer the matter to the FOS.

title: Response Within Fifteen Day
body_md:
{{firm.name}} aims to provide a Final Response within fifteen days of receiving a complaint. The target is to ensure that nearly all complaints received by {{firm.name}} are addressed comprehensively by this time. In cases where a Final Response cannot be issued within fifteen days, {{firm.name}} will send a Holding Response:
- Explanation of Delay: The holding response must only be used in exceptional circumstances and will clearly explain why the complaint has not yet been resolved, outline the steps taken to date, and provide an estimated timeline for the issuance of the Final Response - maximum 35 days.
- Referral to FOS: The response will include information about the complainant’s right to refer the matter to the PSR / FOS and will provide details on how to do so, ensuring that the complainant is informed of their options should they wish to escalate the matter

title: FCA and FOS Assessment of Response
body_md:
Both the FCA and FOS may consider the quality and timeliness of {{firm.name}}’s responses when evaluating its complaint-handling practices. Factors that may be assessed include:
- Whether the response appropriately addresses the complainant’s concerns and provides a clear and reasonable explanation of {{firm.name}}’s findings
- Whether {{firm.name}} communicates the complaint process clearly and provides understandable reasons for its decision, especially if the complaint is rejected
- Whether {{firm.name}} adhered to the fifteen days time limit for a final or holding response, ensuring that delays are minimised
- {{firm.name}} strives to take a proactive approach in resolving complaints early, reducing the need for escalation to the FOS and demonstrating its commitment to delivering positive customer outcomes
In cases where delays are unavoidable, {{firm.name}} takes extra care to keep complainants informed and reassured that their issue is under active investigation.

title: Complaints Forwarding Rules
body_md:
| Regulatory References: •DISP 1.7 (Forwarding Complaints) •DISP 1.2.2R (Complaints Definition) •DISP 1.7.2R (Responsibility for Forwarded Complaints) |
| --- |

{{firm.name}} acknowledges that in certain instances, another firm may be solely or jointly responsible for the subject matter of a complaint. In compliance with DISP 1.7, {{firm.name}} ensures that complaints are forwarded to the appropriate firm in a prompt, transparent, and efficient manner, while maintaining its own obligations in cases of joint responsibility.

title: Forwarding to Another Firm
body_md:
Where {{firm.name}} has reasonable grounds to believe that another firm (e.g., payment provider) may be fully or partially responsible for the complaint, {{firm.name}} will:
- Forward the complaint, or the relevant part of it, to the other firm promptly and in writing. {{firm.name}} ensures that forwarding is done without delay to prevent unnecessary inconvenience to the complainant.
- Once the complaint has been forwarded, {{firm.name}} will promptly notify the complainant in its Final Response. This communication will:
- Explain clearly why the complaint has been forwarded to another firm.
- Provide the contact details of the other firm, enabling the complainant to follow up directly if necessary.
- Reassure the complainant that their complaint is still under review and that {{firm.name}} will continue to monitor progress if it shares responsibility for the issue.
- Where {{firm.name}} is jointly responsible for the fault alleged in the complaint, it will:
- Fully investigate and resolve its own part of the complaint, adhering to all DISP rules and time limits.
- Continue to engage with the complainant and the other firm to ensure a seamless and coordinated resolution.
- Provide clear communication to the complainant about the role of each firm in resolving the matter and the expected timelines.

title: Accountability for Joint Complaints
body_md: In cases of joint responsibility, {{firm.name}} takes its obligations seriously and ensures that its Final Response addresses the parts of the complaint within its control. The complainant is kept informed of {{firm.name}}’s actions, as well as the progress made by the other firm involved. By adhering to these principles, {{firm.name}} ensures that the complaint is handled fairly and transparently, even in cases where multiple parties are involved. Forwarding complaints does not absolve {{firm.name}} of its regulatory responsibilities under DISP, and the firm remains committed to acting in the complainant’s best interests throughout the process.

title: Dealing With A Forwarded Complaint
body_md:
| Regulatory References: •DISP 1.7.1R (Forwarding Complaints Between Firms) •DISP 1.6.2R (Handling of Complaints) |
| --- |

When {{firm.name}} receives a complaint forwarded from another firm under DISP 1.7.1R, it is treated as if the complaint were made directly to {{firm.name}}. This means the same standards, procedures, and time limits apply, ensuring that the complaint is addressed with the same diligence and speed as any complaint received directly from a customer.

title: How MFS Handles Forwarded Complaints
body_md:
Upon receiving a forwarded complaint, {{firm.name}} will send a prompt written acknowledgement to the complainant within three business days. The acknowledgement letter will:
- Confirm that {{firm.name}} has received the complaint from another firm.
- Reassure the complainant that {{firm.name}} is now handling the issue in accordance with its complaints procedure.
- Provide an estimated timeline for resolution, clarifying that standard DISP time limits apply from the day the complaint was forwarded to {{firm.name}}.
Investigation Process
- {{firm.name}} will carry out a thorough and impartial investigation, adhering to the same high standards applied to complaints received directly.
- The Compliance Team will work closely with the relevant business area to ensure all pertinent information, including contracts, terms and conditions, and transaction details, are reviewed. If necessary, {{firm.name}} may request additional information from the firm that initially handled the complaint to ensure a complete understanding of the issue.
- If joint responsibility exists (i.e., both {{firm.name}} and the original firm may share responsibility for the fault), {{firm.name}} will communicate and coordinate with the other firm to ensure the complainant’s concerns are fully addressed. {{firm.name}} will take full responsibility for its own role in the matter and will maintain transparency with the complainant throughout the process.
Compliance with Time Limits
From the moment {{firm.name}} receives the forwarded complaint, the standard regulatory time limits apply:
- Fifteen Days Final Response: {{firm.name}} will issue a final response within fifteen days of the date the complaint was forwarded, detailing its decision and any redress or remedial action to be taken.
- Contingency for delayed responses: In exceptional circumstances beyond our control, we may be unable to issue a final response within 15 business days of receiving your complaint.
- If that happens, we will send the customer a holding reply that:
- explains the reason for the delay
- tells you when you can expect our final response, which will be no later than 35 business days from the day we received the complaint.
Cooperation with the Original Firm: In situations of joint responsibility, {{firm.name}} will ensure the other firm is updated on the progress of the investigation and remains involved in the resolution process if necessary. However, {{firm.name}} will handle its portion of the complaint independently and ensure no undue delays are introduced due to the involvement of another firm.
4.Clear Communication
- {{firm.name}} will keep the complainant informed at each stage of the process. If the investigation reveals that the complaint involves the original firm in any capacity, {{firm.name}} will transparently explain the division of responsibility.
- If the complaint is fully resolved by {{firm.name}}, the complainant will receive a final response letter in line with DISP 1.6.2R, summarising {{firm.name}}’s findings and detailing any redress.
- If the issue remains partially unresolved due to the involvement of the original firm, {{firm.name}} will provide guidance on the next steps and facilitate further communication between the complainant and the original firm if necessary.

title: Commitment to Timely and Fair Outcomes:
body_md: {{firm.name}} is committed to ensuring that forwarded complaints are handled with the same care and urgency as complaints received directly. By adhering to strict time limits, cooperating fully with other firms when necessary, and maintaining transparent communication with complainants, {{firm.name}} ensures that all forwarded complaints result in fair outcomes.

title: Joint Responsibility For Complaints
body_md:
| Regulatory References: DISP 1.7 (Complaints Resolution Rules) PRIN 2A (Consumer Duty) |
| --- |

{{firm.name}} recognises that in some instances, complaints may involve multiple parties. In such cases, {{firm.name}} commits to a collaborative approach to ensure fair and timely resolution for the complainant.

title: Process for Handling Joint Responsibility Complaints:
body_md:
- Upon receipt of a complaint, {{firm.name}} will immediately assess whether other parties, are involved.
- If joint responsibility is identified, {{firm.name}} will: a) Notify all relevant parties within 24 hours of complaint receipt. b) Clearly communicate the complaint details and potential areas of responsibility.
- Within 48 hours of identification, {{firm.name}} will arrange a coordination meeting with all involved parties to: a) Determine primary responsibility for complaint handling. b) Agree on the investigation approach and timelines. c) Establish clear communication channels between parties.
- The primary responsible party will lead the investigation, with other parties providing necessary information and support.
- All parties will provide weekly updates on the investigation progress.
- The primary responsible party will draft the final response, which will be reviewed and agreed upon by all parties before being sent to the complainant.
- Post-resolution, all parties will conduct a joint review to identify improvement areas and prevent similar issues.
Table: Responsibilities in Joint Complaints Handling
| Party | Primary Responsibilities |
| --- | --- |
| {{firm.name}} | Overall complaint management Coordination with other parties Final response drafting Regulatory reporting |
| Other Third Parties (e.g., correspondent banks) | Supplying product-specific information Assisting with technical aspects of the complaint |

title: Complaints Time Barring Rule
body_md:
| Regulatory References: •DISP 2.8.2R (Time Limits for Referral to the Financial Ombudsman Service) •DISP 2.8.7R (Waiving Time Limits in Exceptional Circumstances) •DISP 1.6.2R (Final Response) |
| --- |

In certain circumstances, {{firm.name}} may receive a complaint that it considers falls outside the time limits for referral to theFOS. In such cases, {{firm.name}} is permitted to reject the complaint without considering its merits. However, {{firm.name}} recognises the need to ensure that complainants are fully informed of their rights, and the firm’s responsibilities under the FCA’s DISP rules.

title: How MFS Handles Time-Barred Complaints
body_md:
Assessment of Time Limits
- {{firm.name}} will carefully review any complaint that appears to fall outside the time limits for referral to the FOS. In line with DISP 2.8.2R, this typically includes complaints:
- Made more than six years after the event complained about.
- Made more than three years from the date the complainant became aware (or ought reasonably to have become aware) of the cause for complaint.
- {{firm.name}}’s Compliance Officer will thoroughly review the relevant timelines and confirm whether the complaint indeed falls outside the regulatory limits for referral.
Clear Explanation to Complainants
- If {{firm.name}} determines that the complaint is time-barred, a Final Response Letter will be issued, which must:
- Explain the time-barring decision: The letter will provide a clear and detailed explanation of why {{firm.name}} considers the complaint to be out of time.
- Include a reference to FOS time-limit waivers: The letter must also indicate that in some cases, the FOS may choose to waive the time limits in exceptional circumstances. {{firm.name}} will include wording from DISP 1 Annex 3R, informing the complainant of their right to contact the FOS and request consideration of their case, even if it appears out of time.
- Provide FOS Contact Information: The letter will enclose the FOS’s standard explanatory leaflet, along with the website address and contact details for further information.
Maintaining Fairness
- {{firm.name}} understands that time-barring rules must be applied fairly and consistently. Therefore, {{firm.name}} will ensure that time-barred complaints are handled with care, providing complainants with clear reasons for the decision and ensuring they are aware of any exceptions or options available through the FOS.
Exceptional Circumstances
- In instances where the complainant presents exceptional circumstances, {{firm.name}} will carefully consider whether these circumstances warrant further investigation despite the time limits. This could include cases where the complainant was unable to bring the complaint sooner due to reasons such as ill health, incapacity, or other mitigating factors.
- If exceptional circumstances are identified, {{firm.name}} will either proceed with handling the complaint or, if applicable, recommend that the complainant directly requests a waiver from the FOS.
Ongoing Monitoring
- All time-barred complaints are logged and tracked in the CMS system, and trends are reviewed periodically by the Compliance Team. This ensures that {{firm.name}} continuously monitors whether certain types of complaints are consistently falling outside time limits, allowing for process improvements where necessary.
- If a pattern of time-barred complaints emerges in a particular product area or service, {{firm.name}} will assess whether proactive steps are needed to address the underlying issues and reduce the risk of future time-barred complaints.

title: Ensuring Transparency and Fairness
body_md: By maintaining transparent communication with complainants and rigorously applying DISP rules on time-barring, {{firm.name}} ensures that complainants are fully informed of their rights while safeguarding the firm’s regulatory obligations. {{firm.name}} remains committed to acting fairly and promptly, even in cases where complaints are deemed to fall outside the time limits for referral to the Financial Ombudsman Service.

title: Root Cause Analysis
body_md:
| Regulatory References: DISP 1.3.3R (Complaints Handling Rules) SYSC 6.1.1R (Compliance and Internal Audit) |
| --- |

{{firm.name}} implements a robust Root Cause Analysis (RCA) process to identify and address the underlying causes of complaints, ensuring continuous improvement in our products, services, and processes.

title: RCA Methodology
body_md:
- Trigger: RCA is initiated for:
- All upheld complaints
- Rejected complaints where the customer has escalated to the FOS
- Any complaint types occurring three or more times in a quarter
- Process:
- Data Gathering: Collect all relevant information, including customer communications, product details, and staff actions
- Analysis: Use the '5 Whys' technique to drill down to the root cause
- Categorisation: Classify root causes (e.g., process failure, staff error, product design flaw)
- Action Planning: Develop specific, measurable actions to address the root cause.
- Implementation: Execute the action plan with clear ownership and timelines.
- Monitoring: Track the effectiveness of implemented actions.
- Frequency: Conduct RCA reviews monthly, with a comprehensive quarterly review presented to the Risk Committee.
Example RCA: Complaint: Customers repeatedly complain about unexpected fees in remittance service.
| RCA Step | Details |
| --- | --- |
| Symptom | Customers surprised by fees |
| Why 1 | Fee disclosure not prominent in documentation |
| Why 2 | Current template buries fee information in small print |
| Why 3 | Template designed without customer comprehension in mind |
| Why 4 | Lack of customer-centric approach in document design process |
| Root Cause | Absence of customer feedback in document creation process |
| Action | Implement customer panel review for all new customer-facing documents |

title: Integration with Product Development
body_md:
- Quarterly RCA findings are presented to the Product Development team
- Any product-related root causes must be addressed in the next product review cycle
- The Compliance team signs off on how RCA findings have been incorporated into product improvements

title: Complaints Record Rule
body_md:
{{firm.name}} requires that it keep a record of each complaint received. {{firm.name}} will also keep a log of all complaints forwarded from third parties and the measures taken for their resolution.
In both cases {{firm.name}} must retain records for:
- at least five years, where the complaint relates to MiFID business; and
- three years for all other complaints;
These timescales begin from the date the complaint was received.

title: Complaints Reporting Rules
body_md:
{{firm.name}} is committed to complying with the FCA’s requirements under DISP 1.10, ensuring accurate and timely submission of complaints data. {{firm.name}} recognises that complaints reporting plays a key role in the regulatory oversight of complaint handling and enables the FCA to monitor trends and ensure fair outcomes for consumers.
Electronic Reporting via FCA Systems
All complaints reports must be submitted online through the FCA’s RegData platform in accordance with DISP 1.10.1R. {{firm.name}} will submit its complaints data twice a year, ensuring the data captures all complaints received from eligible complainants relating to activities carried out by {{firm.name}}’s employees, including those acting as retail investment advisers.
Reporting Periods
The reporting periods for {{firm.name}} are:
- The six months immediately following {{firm.name}}’s accounting reference date.
- The six months immediately preceding {{firm.name}}’s accounting reference date.
These periods ensure that {{firm.name}} provides the FCA with up-to-date information on its complaint handling practices and outcomes.
Data Reporting Categories
When preparing the complaints report, {{firm.name}} will adhere to the FCA DISP 1 Annex 1C R format and consider the following factors:
- If a complaint falls into more than one category, {{firm.name}} will assign the complaint to the category that represents the main subject of the complaint.
- Even when complaints are resolved within three business days under DISP 1.5, they will still be included in the complaints data report. Complaints that are upheld in part, or where {{firm.name}} provides a goodwill payment without accepting the complaint, will also be treated as upheld for reporting purposes. However, complaints that are rejected but include goodwill payments will be recorded as rejected.
- When reporting on the amount of redress paid, {{firm.name}} will include:
- Payments for distress and inconvenience.
- Free transfers out to another provider that would normally incur a fee.
- Goodwill payments or gestures.
- Interest on delayed settlements..
- Payments to restore the customer to the position they would have been in if the issue had not occurred.
- Refunds of premiums taken in error, such as overcharges, will not be considered redress and will not be included in the report.
System Failure Contingency
In the event that {{firm.name}} is unable to submit its complaints report electronically due to a system failure, {{firm.name}} will notify the FCA immediately, in writing, providing details of the failure and an estimated timeline for submission once the issue is resolved. This ensures transparency and compliance with DISP 1.10.1R.

title: Complaints Data Summary and Publication
body_md:
In alignment with DISP 1.10A.1R, {{firm.name}} is required to publish a Complaints Data Summary if it submits 500 or more complaints within a reporting period. This data summary provides a transparent overview of the nature and resolution of complaints handled by {{firm.name}}, ensuring stakeholders have access to this information.
Complaints Data Summary Format
The complaints data summary will follow the format prescribed by DISP 1 Annex 1B R and will include:
- The total number of complaints received.
- The number of complaints upheld.
- The amount of redress paid where applicable.
Group Reporting
If {{firm.name}} submits a joint report on behalf of itself and other firms within a group, and the report includes 500 or more complaints, {{firm.name}} will also publish a joint Complaints Data Summary. This ensures that group-level complaint data is transparently shared with the FCA and the public.
FCA Confirmation
After publishing the Complaints Data Summary, {{firm.name}} will send a confirmation email to the FCA at complaintsdatasummary@fca.org.uk, confirming that:
- The complaints data summary accurately reflects the information submitted to the FCA.
- The summary has been published.
- The location of the published summary (e.g., on the {{firm.name}} website).

title: Using MI to Drive Improvement
body_md:

- The Training Department develops an enhanced module on explaining fees to customers

By leveraging comprehensive MI and maintaining a robust reporting framework, {{firm.name}} ensures that complaints data informs strategic decision-making, supports continuous improvement, and ultimately leads to better customer outcomes in line with regulatory expectations and the Consumer Duty.

title: A Closed Complaint
body_md:
| Regulatory References: •DISP 1.5.5R (Definition of a Closed Complaint) •DISP 1.10.2R (Reporting Complaints to the FCA) |
| --- |

A complaint is deemed closed by {{firm.name}} when one of the following conditions has been met, ensuring clarity and consistency in how {{firm.name}} manages and reports on closed complaints:
Final Response Issued
- {{firm.name}} has issued a Final Response to the complainant, in accordance with DISP 1.6.2R, which either:
- Accepts the complaint and offers redress or remedial action;
- Offers redress or remedial action without accepting the complaint; or
- Rejects the complaint with clear reasons provided.
- The Final Response must include the complainant’s right to escalate the complaint to theFOS if they are dissatisfied with the outcome, along with the appropriate contact information and FOS explanatory leaflet.
Written Acceptance from the Complainant
- The complainant has provided written confirmation that they accept {{firm.name}}’s earlier response, even if the complaint is not fully resolved to their satisfaction.
- Once acceptance is received in writing, the complaint is considered closed, and {{firm.name}} logs this as the closure date for reporting purposes.
Lack of Response from the Complainant
- If a complainant fails to respond within fifteen days of receiving a written response from {{firm.name}}, the firm may consider the complaint closed. For the purposes of FCA reporting under DISP 1.10, {{firm.name}} will log the date of its original response as the closure date if the complainant does not reply within the fifteen day period.
- {{firm.name}} will ensure that reasonable efforts are made to follow up with the complainant before considering the complaint closed, such as sending a reminder communication after fifteen days of no response (with a contingency of 35 days). This helps demonstrate that {{firm.name}} is acting fairly and in the complainant’s best interests.

title: Ongoing Monitoring of Closed Complaints
body_md:
•{{firm.name}} will continue to monitor closed complaints through its Complaint Management System, particularly those closed due to lack of response. This ensures that if a complainant later re-engages, the complaint can be reopened and dealt with promptly.
•Root Cause Analysis (RCA) will still be conducted on closed complaints to identify any systemic issues or trends, even if the complainant did not follow up.

title: Notification Of Contact Point For Complainants
body_md:
| Regulatory References: •DISP 1.10.2R (Complaints Data Submission) •DISP 1.11.2G (FCA Register Contact Point Requirements) |
| --- |

To ensure transparency and accessibility for complainants, {{firm.name}} will provide the FCA with a designated contact point for handling complaints. This ensures that any customer, regulatory body, or external party can easily contact {{firm.name}} regarding complaint-related matters.

title: How MFS Handles Complaint Contact Notifications
body_md:
Initial Notification at Authorisation
Upon receiving authorisation from the FCA, {{firm.name}} will provide details of its primary contact point for complaints handling to be listed in the FCA’s Financial Services Register. This ensures that consumers, the FCA, and other stakeholders can easily identify the correct point of contact for any complaints made against {{firm.name}}.
Details of Contact Point:
The designated contact point for {{firm.name}} is:
- Misah Maragh, responsible for the oversight and handling of complaints in compliance with DISP 1.
- Misah Maragh ensures that all complaints are managed effectively and in accordance with the DISP rules, and also coordinates with other teams when necessary to resolve complaints efficiently.
Notification of Changes
{{firm.name}} commits to notifying the FCA of any changes to the designated contact point promptly. This will be done in the next Complaints Data Report submission under DISP 1.10 or at the earliest possible opportunity if the change occurs between reporting periods.nThis includes changes in the individual’s contact details (e.g., phone number or email) or if a new person assumes responsibility for complaints oversight.
Visibility and Public Access
{{firm.name}} will ensure that complainants are provided with the contact details for Misah Maragh in all relevant complaints-related documentation, including acknowledgement letters, final response letters, and other communications. This contact information will also be made available on {{firm.name}}’s website to ensure customers know whom to contact for complaints escalation. Additionally, the Financial Services Register will display {{firm.name}}’s designated contact point to enhance transparency and provide consumers with a reliable source for complaints information.

title: Regulatory Context and Approach
body_md: When a complaint is referred to the FOS, {{firm.name}} recognises the importance of thorough preparation and a strategic response. Complaints referred to the FOS will undergo a comprehensive review process, ensuring that {{firm.name}} maintains full compliance with DISP rules while effectively managing reputational risk and customer relations.

title: FOS Complaint Management Process
body_md:
Internal Review and Preparation Meeting:
- Upon receipt of notice that a complaint has been referred to the FOS, {{firm.name}} will convene a formal meeting to review the case. This meeting will involve key stakeholders, including:
- The Board of Directors: to provide governance oversight and strategic input.
- Complaint Investigator/Compliance Officer (SMF 16): to present the findings of the internal investigation and coordinate {{firm.name}}’s approach to the FOS.
- The purpose of the meeting is to:
- Review the complaint’s background: Examine the evidence, internal correspondence, customer interactions, and any prior decisions made by {{firm.name}}.
- Identify potential risks: Assess the likelihood of an adverse ruling by the FOS and any regulatory or financial risks associated with the complaint.
- Agree on a response strategy: Formulate a clear, defensible position to present to the FOS, ensuring that {{firm.name}} addresses all relevant facts and any regulatory considerations in a transparent manner.
FOS Submission
- Following the internal review, {{firm.name}} will prepare its formal submission to the FOS. This submission will:
- Include all supporting documentation, including customer agreements, communication records, and previous responses.
- Clearly outline {{firm.name}}’s position on the matter, including any offers of remedial action or redress that may have been made during the internal complaints process.
- Demonstrate compliance with the relevant FCA DISP rules, including clear reasoning for the original decision, particularly if {{firm.name}} decided to reject the complaint or offer partial redress.
Ongoing Communication and FOS Engagement
- {{firm.name}} will fully cooperate with the FOS throughout the complaint resolution process. This includes:
- Responding promptly to any requests for additional information or clarification from the FOS.
- Providing regular updates to the complainant, as required by DISP 1.4, ensuring that the customer remains informed of the status of their complaint.
- {{firm.name}} will ensure that its Compliance Officer acts as the key liaison with the FOS, ensuring all responses are consistent and aligned with {{firm.name}}’s regulatory obligations.

title: Time-Barring Decisions
body_md:
{{firm.name}} acknowledges the importance of correctly applying the time limits for referral to the FOS, as outlined in DISP 2.8. To ensure fair treatment and compliance with regulatory standards, the following process is adopted for handling time-barring decisions:
Compliance Oversight
- Any decision to reject a complaint on the grounds of time-barring must be referred to the Compliance Officer (SMF 16) for approval.
- The SMF 16 will conduct a detailed review of the complaint’s timeline to ensure that the decision is consistent with the time limits set out in DISP 2.8. This includes:
- Verifying the date the customer first became aware of the issue.
- Ensuring that the relevant time limits for referring the complaint to the FOS have been exceeded.
Final Response for Time-Barred Complaints
- If a complaint is time-barred, {{firm.name}} will issue a Final Response to the complainant. This response will:
- Clearly explain that the complaint falls outside the time limits for referral to the FOS.
- Inform the complainant of the FOS’s discretion to waive the time limits in exceptional circumstances, as per DISP 2.8.2R.
- Provide the complainant with the necessary information to contact the FOS, including a copy of the FOS explanatory leaflet and relevant contact details, as required under DISP 1.6.2R.
Escalation for Review
- In cases where there is ambiguity regarding the application of time-barring rules, the Compliance Officer may escalate the matter to the {{firm.name}} Board for further discussion and input. This ensures that all decisions are fully considered and comply with both the spirit and the letter of DISP regulations.
Reporting Requirements:
{{firm.name}} will submit complaints data to the FCA in accordance with DISP 1.10, including details on:
- The number of complaints referred to the FOS
- The outcomes of complaints resolved by {{firm.name}}
- Any time-barred complaints and the reasons for their rejection.
{{firm.name}} will use complaints data to identify trends and potential root causes, feeding these insights back into its complaints management processes to drive continuous improvement.

title: Quality Assurance in Complaints Handling
body_md:
| Regulatory References: SYSC 6.1 (Compliance, internal audit and financial crime) PRIN 2A (Consumer Duty) DISP 1.3 (Complaints handling rules) |
| --- |

{{firm.name}} implements a robust Quality Assurance (QA) framework to ensure consistency, fairness, and regulatory compliance in its complaints handling process. This framework supports the delivery of good outcomes for customers and aligns with the principles of the Consumer Duty.
QA Process
- Sample Selection:
- Random selection of 10% of all resolved complaints
- 100% review of high-risk complaints (e.g., vulnerable customers, high-value redress, potential FOS referrals)
- Thematic reviews based on identified trends or concerns
- Assessment Criteria:
- Regulatory compliance (DISP, PRIN, Consumer Duty)
- Adherence to {{firm.name}} policies and procedures
- Quality of investigation and decision-making
- Clarity and empathy in customer communications
- Timeliness of response
- Appropriateness of any redress offered
- Scoring System:
- Each case is scored out of 100, with different weightings for various criteria
- Minimum acceptable score: 80
- Any case scoring below 80 triggers immediate remedial action
QA Scoring Matrix
| Criteria | Weighting | Scoring Guide |
| --- | --- | --- |
| Regulatory Compliance | 30% | 0-10: Major breaches11-20: Minor breaches21-30: Fully compliant |
| Investigation Quality | 25% | 0-8: Inadequate9-16: Satisfactory17-25: Thorough |
| Communication | 20% | 0-6: Unclear/inappropriate/unexpected7-13: Clear but room for improvement14-20: Clear, empathetic, tailored |
| Timeliness | 15% | 0-5: Missed regulatory deadlines6-10: Met deadlines but delays11-15: Prompt throughout |
| Redress Appropriateness | 10% | 0-3: Inappropriate4-7: Reasonable8-10: Fair and well-justified |

title: Review Process
body_md:
- Initial review by QA specialist
- Peer review for any cases scoring below 80
- Senior management review for high-risk or complex cases

title: Feedback Loop
